author: sebastiengllmt
title: Cardano carbon offset dapp
description: Blockchain projects are known by not being eco friendly. Cardano is a PoS that manages energy much better than Bitcoin and other PoW solutions but it is not zero.

f6_assessments.q0:
The Team does not address correctly the Challenge Topic of "The Greate Migration (from Ethereum)" which aims to encourage projects to move to the Cardano Ecosystem from Ethereum. Their Proposal should instead be submitted to the Challenge Topic of "Dapps, Products & Integration" as they plan to provide a product to add value to the Cardano Ecosystem.
I find the Team's definitions of the problem and their solutions are not clearly presented. It would take less time for readers to quickly scan through the Team's proposal if their problem statements and solutions are shown with better structure and bullet points.

The Team does not describe how their project can add value to Cardano's ecosystem. I can see that the Team's solution to Cardano's high carbon consumption does not add monetary value to Cardano, but cost Cardano's ecosystem money (via the paying of Moss token to Moss. Earth). Their proposal, if approved, will not attract additional users to the Cardano ecosystem.
The Team's proposal is asking Cardano to pay for the Carbon emitted by Cardano's ecosystem to the environment. This is a cost to Cardano's ecosystem, and if approved, is not likely to be adopted by other Ecosystems whose focus is more on profits and gains. The ability to scale up the Team's solution is even slimmer given the current crisis within the Crypto Market and Communities.
For the above-mentioned reasons, I give the Team a 1/5 score for Impact.
f6_assessments.q1:
The Team has not provided any website, documents, or team members' LinkedIn as evidence of their experience and capability to implement this project.
There are 8 core positions proposed in this Proposal, but only 3 positions are named, which means that they will need to look for and fill in the other 5 positions in the future.
While there are many Carbon Offset Selling Businesses, the Team only works with Moss. Earth. This raises a lot of questions for the audience. Why don't they keep their Trader options open? Is there any particular reason for selecting Moss. Earth? Are they, and why are they better than any other Carbon Offset Trader? Is there any conflict of interest that needs to be disclosed? Does any of the Team members have shares/benefits from Moss.Earth? There are so many ambiguities regarding the Team's choice of Trader.


Given the large requested fund of USD 120,000, the Team has put little effort into breaking down their budget into specific items. Instead, budget items are provided in percentages with no explanation on why, how, or when they will be spent on the Project.
Without specific and detailed cost items, the audience can't assess the rationality of the budget in particular and the probability of success of this project as a whole.

There is no actionable timeline or milestones given, which shows the team's lack of effort to explain thoroughly their Proposal to the Cardano Catalyst Fund Community.
For the above-mentioned reasons, I give the Team a 1/5 score for Feasibility.
f6_assessments.q2:
There is no clearly defined timeline for the project. Their timeline lacks important milestones such as Fund Raising Phase, Development Phase, and Launch Phase. It is nothing much to say about the Team's timeline apart from the fact that they do not seem to take their proposal seriously by not providing any detailed information on their proposed timeline for readers to evaluate.
There is little information on the Team members' profiles and backgrounds. The most experienced members are technical people, while they must have a capable Market Research Manager on their team to make sure that the Carbon Offset they will be buying is eligible and affordable.
The Team has not invested enough in compiling their budget. The listings of cost items in percentage make their Proposal not trustworthy and potential investors question the Team’s devotion. The high audit cost of 20% total budget shows that the Team is not capable of budgeting and controlling their budget. I do not believe the team is competent at financial planning and controlling, and needs experienced personnel on the team to handle Finances.
This makes it impossible for the Catalyst Fund to track and audit the Project.
For the above-mentioned reasons, I give the Team a 1/5 score for Auditability.

f6_assessments.q0: Only partially I can agree with the statement that “Blockchain projects are known by not being eco friendly”. There are many other Proof-of-Stake Blockchains than Cardano. And I’ve been in some of them there are already Carbon-related projects and idea. That’s actually the main reason why in Cardano ecosystem we need to have such projects, to be competitive enough with others, if we want Cardano to become next currency of the world.
f6_assessments.q1: The Milkomeda team is very known in the Cardano ecosystem. Another company from this proposal Moss.earth seems to be well-experienced, as they are working on the tokenization of carbon credit for a while and their work is audited and certified by reputable companies in the world. The solution and plan look fine.
f6_assessments.q2: Development of the smart contract, implementation of an model, MVP, Audit and Deployment - all these phases it would be easier to audit as the team behind this proposal is very open to communication and collaboration. They are transparent and long-time participants of Project Catalyst, so there are few doubts we’ll have audit problems.

f6_assessments.q0: Cardano is an eco-friendly blockchain thanks to its POS solution, but it still has a small number of emissions to be released into the environment. This proposal offers a solution to neutralize this meager emission of the Cardano ecosystem, leading to an even greener blockchain. Currently, Whole Network TWh energy usage for Cardano is 0.00277429, which is 47000 times more energy-efficient than Bitcoin. In my opinion, this proposal to deal with the emissions of a system is not necessary. They should use these resources to do other more useful things in protecting the environment. On the other hand, this proposal only transfers the MCO2 carbon credit of Moss (a token on the ETH ecosystem) via the Milkomeda bridge; the rest is built entirely on Cardano. This recommendation is therefore not suitable for challenge settings.
f6_assessments.q1: With the number of personnel to build this project listed in detail, this is one of the few proposals of dcSpark that can determine the number of personnel involved, which shows that the proponent is very determined to complete this project according to the set plan. Technically, this proposal includes an estimate of the carbon emissions of the Cardano and Milkomeda C1 ecosystems, which is a qualitative estimate that is not completely accurate. Still, the proponent does not provide a formula or estimation method. In addition, the Moss carbon credit is subject to 3rd party verification, so the risk of the accuracy of this carbon credit is also a risk that the proponent cannot control. For the above reasons, I think that even if this proposal is completed, the community will not care.
f6_assessments.q2: A proposal has a partial calculation that must be estimated, and the calculated number may not be exact. From the outset, the proponent was somewhat superficial in these calculations. On the other hand, this proposal does not know how to measure success or specific goals; the goal here is to burn Moss's MCO2 token.

f6_assessments.q0: '- It is not clear that the problem of needing to build a Dapps related to Carbon offset has nothing to do with the problem posed by the Challenge (The big shift from ETH), Carbon offset has not clearly stated the problem of a blockchain using PoS vs. PoW. Supporting the issue of Carbon as stated but not clear, the proposal has not proposed future expansion of the project if funded and implemented, moreover, the connection is not really clear and highlighted. Regarding the content of the challenge, if it is moved to the Dapps and product section, it is more reasonable, and in the end, the plan is not well prepared, the ideas are not clearly presented and there is a deeper connection with the information. Need to provide for the reader to understand specifically
f6_assessments.q1:
Proposers need to provide more relevant documents, especially need to have specific links related to analysis items on factors: carbon offset, technical, actual evidence, in addition, need more
- Specific information of project participants:
- Past field experience
- Experience participating in blockchain
- Experience related to the project will do
- Profile: LinkedIn, Twitter, Youtube.
In addition to stating the work items to be done, the proposer needs to clearly state the roadmap as a roadmap or timeline to clarify the progress, it must be at least 3 months or 3,6,12 months and have a clear title for implementation. Currently, Implementation Costs are apportioned as a % but people will want to keep track of how much they actually are and specific to each stage and each implementation team
The proposal should clearly divide the number of people doing the work, for example, the number of members Development, management, etc.
Since the project claims to have the support of the Moss Team, it is necessary to state what has been done or prepared as technical elements.
The issue of risks associated with it is also quite sketchy when it is only stated in general that it is supported by Moss Team
f6_assessments.q2: There is no clear roadmap for implementation, this is different from the project completion timetable, the proposed roadmap has specific timelines for what the project will achieve, here it could be 3,6,12 months. In addition to the time, it is necessary to include the milestones that the proponent thinks will achieve specific results, the time to achieve the results should be listed in detail at least by month and each item to be completed. The team has not set up a specific KPI measurement index, just talking about the parameters that will be tracked in general, which helps both the Team and those interested in monitoring the project, helping the project succeed. There is no public channel for people to track how the project is progressing and what results have been achieved.

f6_assessments.q0: Climate preservation should be a priority for everyone living on the planet. The Dcspark team proposed a solution to offset carbon emission from the blockchain to help preserve the planet. As you may know blockchains require energy to function because they run with a consensus mechanism which can be proof of stake or proof of work among others. Proof of stake (Cardano) uses much less energy than proof of work.Now, the goal of the Dcspark team is to create a dapp that will estimate the carbon emission level of Cardano which they will offset by burning moss tokens. On the environmental side, I can clearly see the benefits, but I don’t see how the proposal has identified a problem in this challenge. The challenge is called the great migration from Ethereum and the goal is to attract developers from Ethereum to Cardano. I think that the Dcspark team has to pay attention to details when writing proposals. The team has built some interesting tools on Cardano. I think that I can give a good rating based on that fact and that maybe that this proposal wouldn’t fit in any other challenge. I think that the team is a great asset for the Cardano ecosystem so I’ll give this a positive rating in order to give them a chance to get funded. However in the future, I would like to see this team put more effort on their proposals.
f6_assessments.q1: The Dcspark team is well known in the Cardano network. They have built Milkomeda which is a Cardano sidechain and other tools that are beneficial to the community. For that reason, I have high confidence in the feasibility of this proposal. I think that they have all the technical abilities to implement the proposal in the best possible way. Moreover they have done a good job breaking down the budget. So 40% will be allocated to the development, deployment and bridge coordination. They also decided to put 20% into auditing the code. Smart contract audit is a must for all dapp because any vulnerability can cause major harm to users. 20% of the budget will serve as liquidity for carbon credit for Cardano and Mikomeda. I’m not convinced of the sustainability of this solution. What will happen when the liquidity dries out? Are they relying on Catalyst to get liquidity everytime? I don’t think it’s sustainable and maybe the team can find a solution to make the dapp self-sustaining. 15% of the budget will be dedicated to the management and 5% for catalyst project management. They have provided a roadmap that is convincing. However I suggest adding  timelines to it. Overall I think the project is feasible because the team has experience building good projects.
f6_assessments.q2: I think that the project is auditable because they have provided a roadmap that can be used to track its progress. However I would suggest to the team to add a timetable to the roadmap. It should help the community set expectations of the completion of the work. That said, the roadmap is divided into 7 phases. The fisrt phase will consist of  “Development of the smart contract and model to measure carbon emissions in Cardano and Milkomeda C1''. The second phase will be the Implementation of a model upgrading mechanism and Oracle integration. Atfer that there will be an MVP, quality assurance and testing. The next phase will be the smart contract auditing which should help fix all bugs and potential exploits. Then there is the phase of deployment and the moss toke integration and liquidity management. The roadmap sounds promising. Unfortunately the timing is lacking. That’s definitely a point that can be improved. In regards to the success of the project, the metric to check is pretty stratforward. The only metric described by the proposers is the capacity to offset the carbon emission of the blockchain. Altogether, I think that the project is auditable.

f6_assessments.q0:
Currently, cryptocurrencies, best known as Bitcoin, are said to consume a lot of electricity and are not environmentally friendly.
Cardano is being welcomed by the community for its advantages of low energy consumption and environmental friendliness.
Proposal is a challenging problem. Development of ecosystem carbon emission model, can make carbon neutral.
Creating a Dapp that estimates carbon emissions is the solution. This aims to burn Moss tokens to offset its environmental impact each month and make it carbon neutral.
Ecosystem value will be confirmed more with this proposal.
No potential risk is offered.
I would like to ask if the carbon credit tokens put into the Cardano chain are not compatible, how to fix it.
The idea of ​​the proposal is great when the issue of global warming is being concerned, reducing the amount of carbon released into the environment will be a good impression on the community. I support this project
f6_assessments.q1:
The table lists the team of the proposal with all the components related to the project, but we need a detailed table of information about the people and the experience they have for us to verify. Currently we do not see the proposal team with members in charge of what stages of the project.
Detailed budget with work plan.
I see a lack of timing information in this table.
How long will the project be done, what is the timeline that needs to be completed for a work item to track.
The project needs to add more details about the detailed work plan to evaluate the feasibility of the project
f6_assessments.q2:
Success is compatible with the target challenge.
"Make the Cardano blockchain's carbon footprint neutral"
Technical people will attest to this.
The non-specialist community will verify by reviewing the reports submitted by the proposal publicly.
The number of PoS developed on Cardano is also a measure of the success of the project
The project progress is tracked by each work item given with the accompanying detailed report that will be a plus point for the transparency of the project.
A new proposal, welcome to the team of the proposal to Fund 9

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal does not address the challenge of Migration from Ethereum. The proposal suggests tokenisation of a carbon credit to offset the impact from minimg on Milkodeda and stake pool operations on Cardano. In my opinion there are very small with respect to other blockchains AND should be offered at the app level, or sidechain level.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal mentions a team that has some common names in it, all member of the Cardano community and well respected. I dont see any reason not to trust their level of skill to get this project done. However, with a budget of $120K i dont htink there has been a sufficient breakdown of how these funds will get uesd and i dont believe that it woudl take $120K to mint a token, and offer it to projects , dapps or sidechains to offset any carbon footprint.
f6_assessments.q2: I dont believe there is a clear plan to the projects timeline that has been presented, other than a very standard software/smart contract development timeline. There are no details abotu how to measure how many "users" adopt the carbon token and how they use it. No mention of where the proceeds of the offset will go and the toeknomics behind it.

f6_assessments.q0: This proposal highlights the problem that Cardano is a PoS that manages energy much better than Bitcoin and other PoW solutions but it is not zero and offers a solution in the way that the development of a carbon emission model for Cardano and Milkomeda C1. a smart contract that supports carbon credit tokens from Moss.earth. The idea is phenomenal, but it does not fit into this challenge in any way. It would be good if the proposer worked out key metrics and goals that would meet the challenge settings.  Because there are no KPIs, it's hard to compare KPIs with challenge setting and the proposal is not able to scale to address future challenges. It would be great if the proposer presented in detail how this proposal will add value to the Cardano ecosystem.
f6_assessments.q1: Unfortunately, we do not have social network links or a website link from which we could see if these are real people and if these people have the necessary experience, knowledge and skills to realize this idea. The budget was presented, but it was not within normal limits and a detailed budget breakdown was not made. It would be great if the community had an insight into what the requested $120,000 will be spent on and how. For such great ideas, it is necessary to create a work plan with clear time frames within the idea will be turned into a project and realized. In every project, including this one, especially when there is an idea to ask for such a large amount, there must also be an idea about possible risks, and they need to be worked out and a solution offered.
f6_assessments.q2: For this kind of idea, I would like to see a detailed roadmap with milestones and clearly developed and presented KPIs, so that the community can be engaged and involved in the monitoring of such ideas. It would be great if the proposer, together with his team, would join the weekly gatherings where he would surely get quality information about the Catalyst project and the rest.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal tries to create a smart contract that supports carbon credits tokens from Moss.earth
, thus the emissions of the ecosystem can be made carbon neutral. The proposal wants to tackle a serious problem, which if can be implemented successfully the impact on the Cardano ecosystem will be immense. As the dcSpark team already getting support from the Moss.earth team and considering dcSpark impressive track record, the chance of project success is high. However, some parts of the proposal can be written in more detail.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal provide various and clear milestones of the project, however, those milestone are not tied to a specific timetable/timelines. Proposers provide a budget breakdown but some items can be written in more detail. For example the development and deployment can be broken down into costs/hours, so the community can determine if the proposed budget is reasonable. The proposal provide names and their respective role on the project. However, it can be better if proposers also outline background, experience, and relevant skills of each team  member. So the voters and community can be convinced the team is able to deliver the plan.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal does not explain any way how the community can track the project progress, instead they copy-pasted the milestones on the feasibility section to the auditability section. It will be much better if the proposal provides a Github repo/monthly report or other accessible documentation of the project's progress to the community. The defined success is clear since the project purpose is also straightforward.

f6_assessments.q0: Being environmentally friendly will become more and more important as time goes on for any ecosystem. Many proof-of-work cryptocurrencies, including Ethereum, are attempting to switch to proof-of-stake to cut down on energy use and carbon emissions. Due to the fact that it is already proof of stake, Cardano has an advantage over other cryptocurrencies in terms of environmental friendliness. Being environmentally friendly will be one of the key considerations for investors before they make an investment. Although the cardano emits very little carbon, the proposer would like to make it carbon neutral, which would be very beneficial for the cardano ecosystem. The proposer's proposed solution does address the issue and solve it. Future funding requests will be made in order to refill the smart contract with more carbon credits, and a similar proposal can be made again with a more effective way to achieve carbon neutrality. As a result, this proposal can be scaled to address challenges that will arise in the future. The proposal effectively addresses the issue.
f6_assessments.q1: To put this proposal into action, the proposer will collaborate with Moss.earth. The key developers of Milkomeda and Moss.earth, who are the proposers, have been working successfully on the tokenization of carbon credits. Their work has been audited and certified by well-known organizations around the world. Therefore, it is safe to assume that the proposer has the necessary expertise to carry out this proposal successfully with Moss.earth. The amount of money requested has been divided into the percentages required to pay for the project's costs. The amount requested is reasonable for the work that needs to be done, according to the fund breakdown. The proposal states that no further development will be required, so no additional funding will be required for development; however, additional funding will be required to refill the smart contract with more carbon credits, which makes sense. The proposal includes a detailed list of tasks that must be completed in order to carry out the proposal successfully. The proposal's auditability may be affected because the proposer has not provided an estimate of when the project will be completed or any timeline. The proposal execution plan makes sense. The proposer has considered all possible resources that may be needed to carry out the proposal. There is no risk associated with the implementation of this project. As a result, it is highly likely this proposal will be implemented successfully
f6_assessments.q2: The proposer has provided clear milestones for delivering the proposal, but no time horizon or timeline has been provided, which would have made auditing the progress easier. The proposer stated that the proposal's progress can be measured by the completion of each phase of the project. Making the Cardano blockchain carbon emission neutral and keeping it running as long as there is funding for the purchase of carbon credit from Moss.earth will be the proposal's success. The proposer has provided a clear explanation of the problem of making the Cardano ecosystem carbon emission neutral, and the proposer is attempting to resolve it by developing a dApp that estimates Cardano's carbon emissions. It can also burn Moss tokens to offset its monthly environmental impact and become carbon emission neutral, effectively resolving the issue. This proposal doesn't require any key performance indicator and SDGs. The information provided is sufficient to audit the progress and the success of the proposal.

f6_assessments.q0: I am inclined to agree with the contribution the proposal might give. The plan aims to develop a smart contract that accepts tokenized carbon credits from Moss.earth in order to make ecosystem emissions carbon neutral. The proposal seeks to address a significant issue that, if adopted, will have a significant influence on the Cardano ecosystem. The Moss.earth team has already offered its support to the dcSpark team, and given dcSpark's stellar track record, the likelihood of the project succeeding is strong. The proposal can, however, be written in more detail in some places.
f6_assessments.q1: I can't entirely support the proposed plan as presented. The proposal outlines several distinct project milestones. However, there is no set schedule or deadline for those milestones. Budget breakdowns are provided by the proposers; however, some expenses can be stated in greater depth. To enable the community to assess whether the proposed budget is realistic, development and deployment, for instance, can be broken down into hourly costs. Names and descriptions of each party's responsibilities are given in the proposal. However, it would be preferable if proposers additionally included a brief summary of each team member's qualifications, experience, and pertinent skills. In order to persuade the voters and community that the team can carry out the plan,
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal makes no mention of how the community might follow the project's development. The milestones were instead copied and pasted from the auditability section to the feasibility section. It would be much better if the proposal gave the community access to a Github repository, a monthly report, or some other readable record of the project's development. Since the project's goal is also unambiguous, the definition of success is equally uncomplicated. Thus, it is unclear whether or not the provided information is sufficient for us to keep track of.

f6_assessments.q0:
Although the Cardano blockchain operates under a POS mechanism that is considered to be quite environmentally friendly, to operate the system requires thousands of active computers. It also has a negative impact on the environment. I think this project, although not directly affecting many other projects on the cardano ecosystem, it will create sympathy with organizations and governments. This will support Cardano's sustainability. One more thing the project will make our living environment better. That is the greater benefit.
Another aspect, through the Mikomeda bridge, this project also increases the interaction between Blockchain cardano and Etherium
f6_assessments.q1: The development team has confirmed its reputation in the blockchain market. They've got quality products like Mikomeda. I think they have the capacity to complete this project. The proposal has divided development stages but not specific on time. I suggest giving each task a timeline.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal does mention costs but is not specific. I suggest that there should be a more specific table of costs for each stage and each task. The proposal also does not provide KPIs. This will make it difficult to check progress in each phase. The success of proposals can only be assessed when they are completed.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal is to develop a carbon emission model for Cardano and Milkomeda C1, which will allow for the offsetting of carbon emissions and making the ecosystem carbon emission neutral. The solution will also include the addition of Moss tokens to the Cardano ecosystem through the Milkomeda. This proposal fits with the challenge of 
"Projects who were either planning to or did launch on an EVM-based blockchain deploy in the Cardano ecosystem and can do so easily."
f6_assessments.q1:
The team behind this proposal is a highly qualified team. We can find developers from Milkomeda (one sidechain solution to connect Ethereum and Cardano) and developers from Moss.earth who have worked on the tokenization of carbon credit with huge success.

The proposal has a budget of $120,000 distributed as follows:
- 40% Development, Deployment and Bridge Coordination
- 20% Audit
- 20% Liquidity for Carbon Credit for Cardano and C1
- 15% Management
- 5% Catalyst Project Management

I would like to see a more detailed and defined budget. You can indicate how each percentage is distributed internally.
f6_assessments.q2:
The proposal explains the different phases of the project but does not propose any metrics to follow the development of the project. Some suggestions could be to make the code public or take metrics from the people who use the service.

Project success is defined as: "Making the Cardano blockchain carbon emission neutral for as long as there is funding for the purchase of carbon credit from Moss.earth" I think the success of the project is quite optimistic. Making Cardano carbon neutral with a single project is a difficult task.

f6_assessments.q0:
To slow the development of Blockchain, governments and the media have always relied on blockchains that emit a lot of carbon, which is harmful to the environment. People misunderstand the Cardano blockchain, which emits very little carbon when compared to other blockchains. This proposal is a fantastic way to provide people with data demonstrating that the Cardano block chain emits very little carbon. In addition, the collaboration with Moss Earth to reforest the forest aids in the absorption of carbon emissions. This increases the adoption of the Cardano ecosystem from nature-loving users as well as users from other blockchains, providing them with a better perspective and increasing the migration of their assets to a better ecosystem that is more environmentally friendly. However, I think the team should include in the risk section that while the risk is quite low, it is also possible that Moss Earth will stop cooperating with this proposal, or users may not believe in the carbon emissions that the team provides, or there is a risk of using group over budget.
With many partners migrating to the Cardano ecosystem, I believe this proposal is appropriate for the challenge and award it 4 points.
f6_assessments.q1:
There are a few unspecified positions in this proposal, but the members who can be identified are well-known online and have years of experience in their respective fields.
In addition, I understand the group's strategy. However, the group has not specified a timetable for carrying out the plans, nor has it provided a clearer explanation for the community to better understand this proposal and to determine the viability of this proposal
As a result, I think that if the project is funded, the proposal's completion will be delayed. It would be preferable if the proposal could be more detailed in these sections, so I award this section 3 points.
f6_assessments.q2:
With the group's knowledge and experience, I fully respect the team; however, I believe the group has members who are technically specialized, so I believe the group's presentation of this proposal is not professional. If funded, I believe the group should hire more people who specialize in professionally presenting and editing ideas in order to respect the community. 
Back to the point. To improve transparency, I believe the team should detail the expenses and whether they are calculated in USD or working time. The metrics are irrelevant to the challenge and no one can measure the project's success, I give this section 3 points.

f6_assessments.q0:
About the idea of ​​reducing carbon consumption in the environment it is a very good idea and has a lot of value in terms of environmental protection.
I have met many projects with the same goal such as KlimaDao on Polygon but now it is alive and well.
If I look at the requirements set by the Challenge, I think this proposal will very well address the requirements set by the Challenge.
But if I look at it from the user's perspective, I see that the feasibility and applicability of this dApp will not be high and few people will pay attention and use it.
As the end problem this dApp creates is to buy back Moss tokens and burn this token. This means reducing the amount of Cardano in the environment. The problem here is who will buy this token and burn it.
If you create a dApp that is highly functional and generates revenue from transaction fees. You use that money to buy Moss code to reduce the amount of Cardano, it will be much more reasonable. When you build a dApp to measure Carbon emissions from Cardano and Milkomeda C1. So where will you get the money to buy the Moss code and burn it. This issue I see the author has not mentioned.
So if the assessment of this proposal effectively solves the Challenge I think Yes Still this proposal creates an effective and sustainable product I think No
f6_assessments.q1:
I have been following the dcSpark team for a long time and I know that they are a very competent team. Their team has talented members who have worked for EMUGRO for a long time, so the issue of expertise I don't think is the problem.
In this proposal, they are very detailed compared to other proposals they have written in Fund9. It is possible that the author and the team have high hopes for this proposal to be funded. So information about team members is introduced in much more detail. Interested voters can check out their chief technology officer here: https://twitter.com/SebastienGllmt.
Since they are celebrities, they don't need to give links to prove their competence. That's the note I wanted to send to new voters who don't know dcSpark.
In the proposal, the author has detailed the implementation plan of this proposal, although it is still quite sketchy compared to other proposals. But this is the most detailed plan their team has written in Fund9.
With a team that has good capabilities and has worked on other products that have been very successful, I believe this proposal will not be too difficult for them.
f6_assessments.q2:
The information provided by the author is sufficient for me to see the success of the proposal. I hope the other proposals they write should be more detailed, out of respect for the reviewers and the voters who voted for them.
Even though they have good abilities, they should still do it more carefully and with more care.
Looking at the work history and implementing the recommendations along with the information provided by the author I see they will complete the proposal excellently. I'm just concerned about the effectiveness of this dApp once it's up and running. That's who will use it and how does this dApp generate revenue and cash flow for the Moss token acquisition. That is a huge problem.

f6_assessments.q0: This is a forcefully defined problem in the Great Migration challenge. Yet, the problem is very subjectively with energy consumption. However, the solution is very much only at conceptual level with Moss.earth via a Smart Contract token. It would be controversial how much this solution can help to reduce the energy consumption level from Cardano Blockchain technology consumption. The chosen of Moss.Earth and the cooperation with Mikomeda Devs also posed a challenge of transparency. It is also no risks involved in this project thus pose a sense of complacency of the proposers. What could been done better is that there should be more well-researched for alternative providers as well as a demo for this proposal. The detail of the partnership between Moss team and dcSpark team would also need to be highlighted as this is the core successful factor of this proposal.
f6_assessments.q1:
The prominent thing is the high budget request up to 24% of the total Challenge Setting, however the budget is very much light described at a very conceptual level. There is no milestone attached to this project for the community to know when will it be finished and monitored. Some of the core team who worked on this project would also need to be shared here for either is it a vacant position (to be hired) or a verifiable account of current team member.
The only great thing about this project is the team dcSpark which is very well-known a reliable  the Cardano Community. However, they applied  10 proposals this Catalyst Fund 9 with the same project lead is Sebastien Guillemot. The PA is a huge fan of dcSpark and have lots of respect for Sebastien, however it would be a concern for the feasibility of delivery of 10 proposal all get funded. It would be much more for the team to complete all 10 proposals. It is a suggestion from the PA to show a more updated frequently milestones and team resources allocation so that the Cardano Community can keep track and follow through this proposal.
f6_assessments.q2: There is not really measurable KPI/OKR indicator for this proposal. It is also no timing attached for the project delivery. The ambition is very inspirational however the how to get there by milestones is missing, moreover, the adoption of this even after the team finish  the smart contract for mco2 token is highly recommended for the real migration to happen. What is the Migration plan is highly recommended for the current Ethereum users. What also needs to be highlighted is the Sustainable Development Goals in relation to the new aim of Cardano Catalyst this Fund. This project is such a great match for many SDGs especially the Environmental related Goals. In overall, the proposal is worth receiving an encouragement for such an innovative a bold idea to attract the Ethereum community.

solution: Development of a carbon emission model for Cardano and Milkomeda C1. a smart contract that support carbon credit tokens from Moss.earth, the emissions of the ecosystem can be made carbon neutral
experience: We are some of the core developers of Milkomeda working with Moss.earth. Moss.earth has been working on the tokenization of carbon credit with huge success and their work is audited and certified by reputable companies in the world like Armanino, Perkinscoie, Verra, EY etc
